awd_titl_txt: The Influence of Mercury's Magnetosphere on Its Outermost Atmosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
Many different processes can free atoms from the surface of the planet Mercury. Most atoms then fall back to Mercury's surface. However, some atoms having higher energies can be picked up and pushed by the sun's radiation, extending Mercury's thin atmosphere farther away from the sun. During Mercury's orbit around the sun, the contributions of all of these processes change at different times. Monitoring the signals from emissions of sodium atoms is an excellent way to trace these processes as they occur during Mercury's orbit. The investigators will build an instrument that can see Mercury's surface and its thin atmosphere at the same time, so that they can measure and model sodium's activity in order to understand Mercury's surface/atmosphere processes. This instrument will be installed on a Japanese telescope located in Hawaii.  This project will involve a new collaboration between Japanese and United States astronomers, fostering international co-operation that benefits the U.S. The results of this work will be included in university astronomy classes, benefiting student education.


Atoms can be liberated from the surface of the planet Mercury by many processes, including photon-stimulated desorption, thermal evaporation, ion sputtering and meteoroid vaporization. Most of these atoms follow a ballistic trajectory, and return to the planet's surface. However, those atoms released with higher energies can be accelerated by solar radiation pressure, creating a coma-like extension of Mercury's exosphere. The relative contributions of these mechanisms to the exosphere are disputed, and recent modeling suggests that no single source mechanism dominates during the entire Mercury year. The investigators will build a new instrument for spectral high-definition imaging to conduct regular, ground-based observations of sodium on Mercury and in its exosphere. Sodium is an excellent tracer of the morphology and dynamics present in Mercury's exosphere system. By producing near-simultaneous spectral images of the sodium brightness enhancements above Mercury's surface and the anti-sunward variations in exospheric sodium, the variability of both sources can be tracked. The observations will then be comprehensively modeled. This investigation will strengthen international collaboration between the Japanese Tohaku University and Boston University through joint observations at the Tohuku 60 cm (24")Telescope on Haleakala, Hawaii. The results from the research will be incorporated into university classes.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this award was to create a unique new instrument capable of obtaining high-resolution spectral images of extended objects.  In particular, our primary focus was to first demonstrate the instrument by using it to map sodium emissions in Mercury's tenuous atmosphere in order to learn about how objects are weathered in the harsh environment of space. 

First, a little bit of background.  Mercury is generally thought of as a dead rock floating in space.  However, it is constantly exposed to intense solar radiation, micrometeorite impacts, and buffeting by the solar wind, a stream of charged particles emanating from the Sun.  These energetic events cause specks of Mercury's surface to be lofted upward, creating a temporary and tenuous atmosphere that falls back to the surface or escapes to space as readily as it is created.  Some atoms in this transitory atmosphere can absorb solar radiation, imparting momentum and pushing them anti-sunward into a comet-like tail.  By studying the response of thin atmospheres such as Mercury's to space weathering we learn about the surface evolution of such bodies.  These weathering processes, in turn, are valuable signatures of the surrounding space environment.

Sodium, in particular, has strong resonant lines that make it especially responsive to solar radiation pressure as well as bright (and therefore easy to observe from the ground).  It is not the dominant constituent of Mercury's surface, but it is a valuable tracer of the surface and atmospheric evolution. Thus, sodium emissions have played a prominent role in historical studies of thing atmospheres at Mercury, the Moon, and throughout the Jupiter system.  In order to detect emission from Mercury's atmosphere, however, a high spectral resolution instrument is needed -- otherwise the weak atmospheric signal is lost within the dark solar Fraunhofer lines caused by absorption in the Sun's outer envelope.  Therefore, spectrographs -- which yield intensity versus wavelength along a narrow spatial slit on the sky -- as opposed to imagers have predominantly been used for studying Mercury's atmosphere, despite the fact that spatial maps would be particularly useful scientifically.

Recent developments in detector technology, software processing and rapid data storage haven enabled low-cost High Definition Imaging (HDI) techniques, commonly called "lucky imaging".  Typical astronomical images follow from extended integrations using larger and larger telescopes.  In order to account for the distortions introduced by the Earth's atmosphere, these telescopes often employ adaptive optics, an expensive and complicated approach.  Using HDI, however, it is possible to integrate "after the fact" by taking numerous short-integrations, and then using software to combine only the best of those integrations where the atmosphere was well-behaved.  Modern amateur astronomers regularly take space quality imagines using small aperture telescopes and HDI techniques.

This project led to the creation of an instrument, dubbed the Rapid Imaging Planetary Spectrograph (RIPS), that combines "lucky imaging" with high-resolution spectroscopy.  In one brief integration, an image and a spectrum are obtained simultaneously on the same detector.  By combining many thousands of such integrations, and by scanning the spectral slit across the object of interest, it is possible to build up an HDI spectral map in a matter of minutes.  The fact that the image and spectrum appear on the same detector allows for spatial registration of all of the spectral information (a process that is difficult or sometimes impossible using instruments that obtain separate images and spectra).

Using data from RIPS' first few campaigns, we were able to map Mercury's sodium atmosphere, finding it to be dynamic and asymmetric.  There are two polar hotspots: these are located near Mercury's magnetic poles, and the temporal variability of the intensity of these hotspots indicates a close connection between Mercury's atmospheric source and the solar wind, as these charged particles are guided by Mercury's magnetic field, causing enhanced impact in the magnetic polar regions.  Thus, RIPS has been able to reduce some of the uncertainty regarding the drivers of Mercury's atmosphere by demonstrating a clear response to the precipitation of solar wind particles.

The RIPS instrument has now been deployed at a number of facilities.  It is relatively compact, easy to transport, and has user-friendly software, and therefore is now well-suited to being used as a community instrument.  Further, its development has been spearheaded by two early career scientists and involved contributions from numerous undergraduate researchers, therefore contributing to significant instrumental, observational, data analysis, and administrative training.  Our plans at present are to expand upon RIPS' first scientific results by establishing a long-term observing campaign in support of the BepiColombo spacecraft, now en route to Mercury, with flybys beginning in 2021 and arrival in 2025.
